content: today i'm going to show you three teeny tiny things that you can craft to add on
to your miniature builds hey guys welcome back to blackmagic
craft little tiny add-on details can really do a lot to enhance a simple
terrain piece go from very basic to something a little bit more interesting
and this is not only true of terrain this applies to miniature bases dioramas
model railroad stuff fairy gardens christmas villages
whatever your miniature hobby of choice may be so today i'm going to share with
you three simple things that you can make in
bulk ahead of time to add on to your builds mine are kind of
themed around the underdark but can certainly be applied to other things
and the reason i wanted to add on to my like little underdark terrain set from a
couple weeks ago was because i had just painted this really sweet ettercat mini
from my friend danny's kickstarter danny is one of my
closest friends from far away and i want to give a bit of love to his
massive kickstarter that he's just wrapping up the lost adventures vol 2
is a different kind of 3d miniature printing kickstarter it includes some
really crazy printable terrain miniatures
as well as rpg content designed for those models danny is an rpg player and
this whole project is made for tabletop rpg players and game
masters there's a lot of companies providing
printable models these days but they're often kind of more delicate and geared
towards painters instead of gamers the models in
this set are sculpted with d d players in mind
the models are a lot chunkier and heftier and don't
have too many really fine little detailed bits that
are going to break really easily and i love that these are models minis
that are meant to be grabbed and thrown around a table
and played with in d d they're not meant to just sit on a shelf and
look nice the kickstarter is just ending but it'll be open for late pledges if
you don't catch it in time i'll put a link in the video description so you can
check it out it would really mean a lot to me if you sent danny some love and
grabbed some of these models for yourself now let's get cracking making
these little add-ons
crystals are a great thing to add to
scatter terrain a lot of people opt for carving them out of hot glue but
personally i'm not a fan of that usually end up with very large crystals
which is fine if that's what you want but
they look better alongside minis if they are a bit smaller
to make smaller ones that are nice and rigid and won't melt in a hot car
i like to use old plastic sprues this is actually one of the few
materials cheaper than hot glue because it's
leftover garbage so it's free they can easily be carved out of flat sections of
sprue using an exacto knife one thing that
makes the process easier is to carve the shape
while it's still attached to a bit of sprue that you can hold onto rather than
trying to carve a little teeny tiny piece
it's a good idea to cut the bases at slight angles so
they aren't just all standing perfectly upright at 90 degrees
when you have a couple you can glue them in clusters to something like a popsicle
stick this will make them easier to paint but it will also give you usable
sort of little tufts of crystal that you can apply in one go to your pieces later
rather than individually placing each length
great thing about using plastic rather than hot glue is that it's a lot easier
to get paint to stick to it i just spray primed them white before
applying any color and you can do any color you want and
get creative and make a bunch of different ones
the paint job is pretty simple just apply a thin
base coat of a darker color and don't worry if you have brush marks brush
marks actually help with a look then just use increasingly brighter
colors to dry brush and highlight the edges
again if you get some scratchy brush marks this is totally fine
it'll actually look appropriate on these and just look like
veining or scratches on the crystals this works especially
well if you end up going with any kind of icy color scheme
after painting it can help to add a glossy coating and you can use gloss
varnish gloss gel gloss mod podge whatever
you've got lying around just to give it a little bit of shine
once you have your clusters pre-made and painted you can just cut them off the
stick and simply glue them onto whatever piece you
want
for the next two items i'm going to be doing a bit of very simple sculpting
you can use many different materials for this it won't affect the outcome very
much but each one has advantages and disadvantages you can use an oven-baked
clay like fimo or sculpey this has endless working time which is great but
then it needs to be baked which requires waiting
it can also react very poorly to a lot of paints
especially spray paints green stuff is a good choice as it's nice and firm and
well suited for these teeny tiny items it can get spray painted after but
you're gonna have to wait several hours for it to cure
millipud is similar in that it can be painted easily but you also have to wait
a really long time for it to cure i also think it's a little bit too soft
for sculpting things this small my preferred material is fast setting
two part epoxy putty this is the kind of thing that you buy at the hardware store
it's great because it cures and hardens in just a few minutes
not great for bigger detailed sculpts but perfect for quick little
forms no waiting no baking and it takes spray paint perfectly
of course in a pinch you could even just use hot glue simple push pins with the
dome sort of tops are essentially ready to use scale mushrooms with a tiny bit
of bending they can look pretty convincing
for larger mushrooms it's a simple matter of applying a bit of whatever
sculpting putty medium you chose to your pins to create mushroom caps of various
shapes and sizes it can be useful to use a bit of
isopropyl alcohol on your fingers and your tools when working with two part
putties it'll prevent sticking but it can also
be used to smooth out fingerprints if needed
leave the pins full length and just put them in a scrap of foam or some
cardboard so that you can easily spray prime them
then you can paint in any number of ways there really isn't going to be a right
way or wrong way to paint mushrooms i mean in real life they come in a
variety of colors and patterns and if you're using them in a fantasy
setting well there's really no limit to the color schemes that
could be possible the great thing about these being made out of pins is that
they can simply be pierced right into a lot of terrain you
don't even need any glue just poke them right in there you
can also use these basic pins right on mini bases to add a nice simple
detail just put them on before you spray prime the model
so that the metal pins get primed at the same time
to create a webbed body or cocoon you're gonna need a slightly humanoid form to
wrap some web around again i'm using the fast
curing putty and applying it directly to a toothpick
this doesn't need to be detailed at all you just want to get a basic shape of a
head a torso and some feet and go ahead and paint it white just in
case some of that shows through the webbing
for the web itself i'm just using basic halloween decorative
web this is the stuff that you can buy for dirt cheap during the halloween
season and it's ideal for this purpose the tricky part about applying this web
is not gluing your fingers to it every step of the way but if you apply a tiny
bit of super glue to the form you can then
wrap it around and around creating that cocoon this is where having that
toothpick handle is really helpful to finish it off and stop the web from
unfurling you just want to add a tiny bit of glue
for this it's a good idea to switch to something like pva so that you can use
your fingers to compress the webs without it getting all stuck to your
skin and thanks to that toothpick handle that
you built it on you can just poke a hole into your terrain and mount these really
easily at whatever angle you want even hanging upside down
it looks a bit weird and naked on its own so you might want to dress it up
with some more added webs or maybe you just
only want to put webs on something again just use that
halloween decoration web it's perfect the trick though is to spread it really
really thin less is definitely more you don't want
it looking too bulky this works really well on terrain that has a lot of
different surfaces and levels for the web to grab
onto once you hit your end point just dab a little bit of super glue to hold
it in place then you can simply cut off any
unsightly excess and you are good to go
well i hope that you found this video
useful and helpful and that these little add-ons maybe make their way
